label: Human Nutrition, Food Safety and Quality

children.label: foodways
children.definition: The eating habits, culinary practices, and food/health beliefs of a people, region, or historical period, focusing on the medicinal, sociological, cultural, psychological and/or historical uses of foods.

children.label: serving size
children.definition: Serving Size on the Nutrition Facts Label is the amount of food that is customarily eaten at one time and is determined based on the Reference Amounts Customarily Consumed (RACC) for foods that have similar dietary usage, product characteristics, and customarily consumed amounts for consumers to make “like product” comparisons.

children.label: Reference Daily Intakes
children.definition: Formerly refered to as the U.S. Recommended Daily Allowances, these guidelines for dietary intake of certain essential vitamins and minerals are independent of total caloric intake.

children.label: Recommended Dietary Allowances
children.definition: The dietary intake level that is sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all individuals in the group.

children.label: Dietary Reference Intakes
children.definition: Dietary Reference Intakes (DRIs) is a term used to refer to at least three types of reference values: Estimated Average Requirement, Recommended Dietary Allowances (RDA), and Tolerable Upper Intake Level. They will gradually replace the RDA.

children.label: Adequate Intakes
children.definition: When sufficient scientific evidence is not available to estimate an average requirement, Adequate Intakes are set.

children.label: Estimated Average Requirement
children.definition: The intake value that is estimated to meet the requirement defined by a specified indicator of adequacy in 50 percent of an age- and gender-specific group. At this level of intake, the remaining 50 percent of the specified group would not have its needs met.

children.label: nutrition assessment
children.definition: Evaluation and measurement of nutritional variables in order to assess the level of nutrition or the nutritional status of the individual. Nutrition surveys may be used in making the assessment.

children.label: dietetics
children.definition: The application of nutritional principles to regulation of the diet and feeding persons or groups of persons.

children.label: Expanded Food and Nutrition Education Program
Food Distribution Program on Indian Reservations
Child and Adult Care Food Program
children.definition: This child nutrition program provides cash and commodity assistance to support meal service programs in child care centers, headstart facilities, and family and group home day care homes for children, the elderly, and disabled. It is permanently authorized under Section 17 of the National School Lunch Act, administered by USDA, Food and Consumer Service, and funded annually by agricultural appropriations.

children.label: community feeding centers
children.definition: Organizations or facilities that prepare or assemble meals for distribution either onsite or offsite to needy recipients who do not reside on the premises. The meals are provided at little or no cost.

children.label: Older Americans Act Nutrition Program
children.definition: The Senior Nutrition Program, authorized under Title III of the Older Americans Protection Act, provides grants to state agencies to support the delivery of meals in dining rooms or at home to seniors of 60 years of age or older. It is designed to address problems of food insufficiency and social isolation among older people.

children.label: Food Distribution Program on Indian Reservations
food banks
children.definition: Umbrella organizations or clearinghouses that solicit marketable and surplus food and grocery products and distribute these products to local nonprofit charities or client agencies, which in turn distribute the food directly to needy individuals and families.

children.label: food pantries
children.definition: Organizations that distribute groceries (non-prepared foods, such as canned goods, cereals, rice, bread and sometimes fresh fruits or meat) to people in need in the community.

children.label: food fads
children.definition: Diets which become fashionable, but which are not necessarily nutritious.

children.label: condiments
children.definition: Seasonings and flavorings that are generally added to foods by the consumer after preparation.

children.label: tripe
children.definition: A retail cut of beef, consisting of the walls of the rumen and the reticulum. Tripe can also come from pork and sheep.

children.label: sweetbreads
children.definition: The thymus glands of veal, young beef, lamb and pork used as food.

children.label: cultured meat
children.definition: Meat produced from the skeletal muscle or muscle cells or stem cells in laboratory conditions by using tissue engineering techniques.

children.label: boxed beef
children.definition: Cuts of beef sealed in vacuum packs to be shipped in cardbard boxes, often ready for retail sale.

children.label: mutton
children.definition: Meat from sheep that are over one year old.

children.label: pork bellies
children.definition: The source of bacon. The pork belly is the lower side of a hog remaining after the loin and spareribs have been removed.

children.label: novel foods
children.definition: Foods produced from ingredients that have not traditionally been used for human consumption in the area of the world in question, or that are produced by a new or extensively modified process.

children.label: low moisture foods
children.definition: Low moisture foods have low water activity and do not support the growth of spoilage or foodborne pathogens. These foods could be naturally low in water activity or that have been dried to lower the water activity.

children.label: natto
children.definition: A Japanese condiment and flavoring which has a glutinous texture and strong cheeselike flavor and is made of steamed, fermented and mashed soybeans.

children.label: douchi
children.definition: Chinese traditional fermented and salted black soybean food product that is rich in proteins.

children.label: miso
children.definition: A fermented soybean paste that may also contain rice, barley or wheat.

children.label: kimchi
children.definition: A Korean dish made of pungent, pickled cabbage.

children.label: fish sauce
children.definition: A pungent, salty seasoning or condiment in Southeast Asian cuisine that is made from fermented anchovies or other fish.

children.label: instant foods
children.definition: Foods in dried form that are ready to eat with the addition of water.

children.label: organic foods
children.definition: Organic food is produced without: antibiotics; growth hormones; most conventional pesticides; petroleum- based fertilizers or sewage sludge-based fertilizers; bioengineering; or ionizing radiation. USDA certification is required before a product can be labeled "organic". Companies, including restaurants, that handle or process organic food must be certified also.

children.label: grain foods
children.definition: Foods that are based completely or primarily on food grains.

children.label: fast foods
children.definition: Foods designed for ready availability, use, or consumption and sold at eating establishments for quick availability or take-out.

children.label: staple foods
children.definition: Foods that are basic to the diet/cuisine of the culture, like wheat flour, rice, corn, yams, sugar, salt, etc.

children.label: processed foods
children.definition: Foods that are manufactured, usually on a large scale, using any of a wide variety of processing techniques, most often with the goal of preserving food for market.

children.label: prepared foods
children.definition: Food products that have been manufactured, often with the intention of making food preparation and meal delivery easier for food industry and private consumers.

children.label: ready-to-cook foods
children.definition: Foods that are processed and/or prepared to be ready to cook with very little additional effort.

children.label: raw milk
children.definition: Fresh, unprocessed milk as it comes from a cow, goat or other mammal.

children.label: fresh produce
children.definition: Raw fruits and vegetables.

children.label: verjuice
children.definition: The sour juice of unripe fruits, such as apples, crab apples or grapes, from which an acid liquor may also be made.

children.label: porridge
children.definition: A porridge is a hot cereal that can be made from a variety of ground, chopped or crushed grains, vegetables, legumes etc., which are boiled in water or milk to make it as a mushy dish. It can be soft or thick and is mostly eaten as a breakfast.

children.label: crackers
children.definition: Baked crisp snack foods made from unleavened grain flour dough to which flavorings or seasonings may be added.

children.label: pound cakes
children.definition: A creamy, moist cake that is characterized with firm texture and creamy mouthfeel upon mastication. It contains equal portions of wheat flour, eggs, sugar and butter or margarine.

children.label: sponge cakes
children.definition: A light soft cake, usually made without added fat or shortening and leavened with eggs.

children.label: food groups
children.definition: A food group is defined as the grouping of food items that have similar caloric and nutrient qualities. According to the USDA, the five major food groups are grains, vegetables, fruits, dairy and meat and meat alternatives. A balanced diet should contain something from each of the five major food groups.

children.label: breadings
children.definition: Bread or cracker crumbs used to coat foods.

children.label: genetically modified foods
children.definition: Foods produced from genetically modified organisms. These species have undergone directed modification of their gene complement using such techniques as altering the DNA, substituting genetic material by means of a virus, transplanting whole nuclei, transplanting cell hybrids, etc.

children.label: cocoa powder
children.definition: Ground cocoa solids.

children.label: low acid foods
children.definition: Food with pH values higher than 4.6.

children.label: high fructose corn syrup
children.definition: Syrup made from corn used widely in foods and beverages as a cheaper alternative sweetener to sucrose (common table sugar). It is generated by enzymatic processing of natural corn syrup to produce a liquid most widely composed of 42 or 55% fructose, glucose, and various polysaccharides.

children.label: plant-based foods
children.definition: Foods originating from plant sources.

children.label: edible films
children.definition: Packaging materials that can be directly consumed. They provide barrier and protection, while enhancing quality and safety of food products.

children.label: imitation foods
children.definition: Products consisting of regular foods and/or chemical formulations that may be used in place of the foods they imitate. Often imitation foods are used by consumers for health or economic reasons.

children.label: milk substitutes
children.definition: Foods that are used to replace cow's milk in the human diet, made with nondairy ingredients.

children.label: surimi
children.definition: A processed seafood product that is typically made from Alaskan pollack that is flavored, precooked, and reformed into shapes that resemble shellfish. Imitation crabmeat is an example of surimi.

children.label: cured foods
children.definition: Food that has been treated with salt or nitrate or nitrite to preserve it. A very old method of food preservation.

children.label: seafoods
children.definition: Edible aquatic (freshwater or marine) organisms such as fish, shellfish, or seaweed that is used as food.

children.label: surimi
children.definition: A processed seafood product that is typically made from Alaskan pollack that is flavored, precooked, and reformed into shapes that resemble shellfish. Imitation crabmeat is an example of surimi.

children.label: mortadella
children.definition: A large, seasoned, smoked Italian sausage made of ground pork, beef, and pork fat.

children.label: chorizo
children.definition: A very spicy pork sausage seasoned with garlic and chili powder.

children.label: animal-based foods
children.definition: Foods originating from animal sources.

children.label: dough sponges
children.definition: An intermediate step in the dough making process, usually a fermented mixture of flour, yeast and liquids.

children.label: enriched foods
children.definition: Foods to which nutrients were added in order to replace losses of the nutrient that occured during processing.

children.label: perishable foods
children.definition: Foods that are subject to loss of quality, usually by destruction, decay or spoilage.

children.label: artificially sweetened beverages
children.definition: Beverages sweetened with sweetening agents that are synthetic or artificial as opposed to naturally-occurring. Examples of sweetening agents include aspartame, sucralose, and saccharin.

children.label: alcoholic beverages
children.definition: Drinkable liquids containing ethanol.

children.label: mash
children.definition: A crushed fermentable mixture, typically malt, grain meal or fruit, used to produce alcoholic beverages such as whiskey or beer.

children.label: beers
children.definition: A fermented, carbonated, alcoholic beverage containing one-half of 1 percent or more of alcohol by volume. Generally brewed from malt (mostly barley malt), hops (for flavoring) and water. Other cereals such as corn and rice may be used.

children.label: absinthe
children.definition: An extract of absinthium and other bitter herbs, containing 60% alcohol. Prolonged ingestion causes nervousness, convulsions, trismus, amblyopia, optic neuritis, and mental deterioration.

children.label: wines
children.definition: All alcoholic beverages made from the fermentation of grape juice, other fruits or vegetative parts. Wine may be sparkling or carbonated, made from condensed grape must, made from agricultural products other than the juice of grapes, and includes products sold as wine such as imitation wine, cider and sake.

children.label: dessert wines
children.definition: Wine having an alcoholic content in excess of 14 percent but not in excess of 24 percent by volume.

children.label: table wines
children.definition: Any wine containing less than 14 percent alcohol by volume, usually meant to be served with meals. Not to be confused with sweet wines, dessert wines, fortified wines, etc.

children.label: mead
children.definition: A fermented beverage made of honey, water and yeast.

children.label: fortified wines
children.definition: A wine to which additional alcohol has been added, often in the form of brandy.

children.label: fruit wines
children.definition: Fruit wine is produced by the alcoholic fermentation of juice from ripe fruits and/or berries other than grapes. During production, pure condensed fruit must, fruit brandy, alcohol, and sugar may be added.

children.label: sparkling wines
children.definition: Wine made effervescent with carbon dioxide resulting solely from the fermentation of the wine within a closed container, tank or bottle.

children.label: rice wines
children.definition: An alcoholic beverage made from fermented rice.

children.label: kombucha
children.definition: A fermented tea beverage obtained by the fermentation of sugared black or green tea with yeast, acetic acid bacteria and lactic acid bacteria.

children.label: beers
children.definition: A fermented, carbonated, alcoholic beverage containing one-half of 1 percent or more of alcohol by volume. Generally brewed from malt (mostly barley malt), hops (for flavoring) and water. Other cereals such as corn and rice may be used.

children.label: wines
children.definition: All alcoholic beverages made from the fermentation of grape juice, other fruits or vegetative parts. Wine may be sparkling or carbonated, made from condensed grape must, made from agricultural products other than the juice of grapes, and includes products sold as wine such as imitation wine, cider and sake.

children.label: dessert wines
children.definition: Wine having an alcoholic content in excess of 14 percent but not in excess of 24 percent by volume.

children.label: table wines
children.definition: Any wine containing less than 14 percent alcohol by volume, usually meant to be served with meals. Not to be confused with sweet wines, dessert wines, fortified wines, etc.

children.label: mead
children.definition: A fermented beverage made of honey, water and yeast.

children.label: fortified wines
children.definition: A wine to which additional alcohol has been added, often in the form of brandy.

children.label: fruit wines
children.definition: Fruit wine is produced by the alcoholic fermentation of juice from ripe fruits and/or berries other than grapes. During production, pure condensed fruit must, fruit brandy, alcohol, and sugar may be added.

children.label: sparkling wines
children.definition: Wine made effervescent with carbon dioxide resulting solely from the fermentation of the wine within a closed container, tank or bottle.

children.label: rice wines
children.definition: An alcoholic beverage made from fermented rice.

children.label: energy drinks
children.definition: A beverage that contains caffeine as an ingredient, along with other ingredients, such as taurine, herbal supplements, vitamins, and added sugars. It is usually marketed as a product that can improve perceived energy, stamina, athletic performance, or concentration.

children.label: kombucha
children.definition: A fermented tea beverage obtained by the fermentation of sugared black or green tea with yeast, acetic acid bacteria and lactic acid bacteria.

children.label: spent coffee grounds
children.definition: The waste product that remain in a pot after brewing coffee.

children.label: sugar sweetened beverages
children.definition: Liquids that are sweetened with various forms of added sugars. These beverages include, but are not limited to, soda (regular, not sugar-free), fruitades, sports drinks, energy drinks, sweetened waters, and coffee and tea beverages with added sugars.

children.label: medical foods
children.definition: A food which is formulated to be consumed or administered enterally under the supervision of a physician and which is intended for the specific dietary management of a disease or condition for which distinctive nutritional requirements, based on recognized scientific principles, are established by medical evaluation.

children.label: fortified foods
children.definition: Foods which contain a higher nutrient content above natural levels because of the addition of nutrients during processing.

children.label: sweeteners
children.definition: Substances that sweeten food, beverages, medications, etc., such as sugar, saccharine or other low-calorie synthetic products.

children.label: nonnutritive sweeteners
children.definition: Sweeteners that do not have any significant energy or nutrient content

children.label: finger foods
children.definition: Finger food is food that is eaten directly with hands. It can be an entire meal or part of meal, for example: a piece of fruit or vegetable, cheese on sticks, a slice of bread, French fries, etc.

children.label: dried milk
children.definition: Dairy product made from milk by the removal of 95-98% of the water.

children.label: dried skim milk
children.definition: The product obtained by removing water from pasteurized skim milk. It contains not more than 5% moisture and not more than 1.5% milk fat unless otherwise indicated.

children.label: ice milk
children.definition: Ice milk is similar to ice cream but it contains less milk fat (2-5 % vs. 10%) and milk solids(11-14%) and has a lighter, less creamy texture.

children.label: functional foods
children.definition: Foods that are considered, by nature or manufacture, to contain significant levels of biologically active components which provide desirable health benefits beyond basic nutrition.

children.label: appetizers
children.definition: A small amount of food, generally eaten just before the main meal.

children.label: fish sauce
children.definition: A pungent, salty seasoning or condiment in Southeast Asian cuisine that is made from fermented anchovies or other fish.

children.label: reconstituted foods
children.definition: Foods which were concentrated or condensed and have been brought to their original strength by adding water.

children.label: milk equivalent
children.definition: The quantity of fluid milk used in a processed dairy product, usually expressed on a milk fat basis, e.g. one pound of cheese is the equivalent of 9.88 pounds of milk.

children.label: bioactive food compounds
children.definition: Bioactive food compounds are extra-nutritional constituents that are found in small amounts in foods and are usually linked with beneficial effects in an organism.

children.label: milk fat
children.definition: Lipid component of animal milks.

children.label: anhydrous milk fat
children.definition: A dairy product made from cream or butter containing at least 99.8% milk fat and 0.10% moisture.

children.label: p-anisidine value
children.definition: A measurement of the aldehyde content in a fat or oil. As aldehydes are secondary oxidation products produced during lipid oxidation, the p-anisidine value measures the oxidative status of the fat or oil, correlating with its flavor quality.

children.label: gastronomy
children.definition: The science and art of good eating and drinking.

children.label: foodomics
children.definition: A discipline that deals with food science and nutrition through the application of advanced omics (genomics, proteomics, metabolomics, etc.) technologies to improve consumer health and well-being.

children.label: food analysis
children.definition: Measurement and evaluation of the components of substances to be taken as food.

children.label: food quality
children.definition: Ratings of the characteristics of food including flavor, appearance, nutritional content, and the amount of microbial and chemical contamination.

children.label: food spoilage
children.definition: Varying degrees of physical, chemical and/or biological deterioration of food sensory properties, nutrient content, and/or safety. Major causes include: 1) growth and activity of microorganisms, 2) natural enzymes, 3) insects, parasites and rodents, 4) temperature, 5) moisture and dryness, 6) air/oxygen, 7) light, 9) time.

children.label: defect action levels
children.definition: Levels of natural or unavoidable defects in foods that present no health hazards for humans.

children.label: food surfaces
children.definition: The surface of any food or food product.

children.label: falling number
children.definition: A method for the determination of the effect of alpha amylase activity during the baking process.

children.label: food matrix
children.definition: The nutrient and non-nutrient components of foods and their molecular relationships, i.e. chemical bonds, to each other.

children.label: nutritive value
children.definition: An indication of the contribution of a food to the nutrient content of the diet. This value depends on the quantity of a food which is digested and absorbed and the amounts of the essential nutrients (protein, fat, carbohydrate, minerals, vitamins) which it contains. This value can be affected by soil and growing conditions, handling and storage, and processing.

children.label: biofortification
children.definition: An increase in the nutritional value of plant foods obtained through convential crop breeding methods or through crop genetic engineering techniques. This contrasts with postharvest fortification in which nutrients are added during processing.

children.label: protein efficiency ratio
children.definition: An assessment of dietary protein quality by calculating weight gain divided by intake of a specific protein during a given period.

children.label: metabolizable energy
children.definition: The net energy in food or feed that is available to humans or animals by digestion and absorption, and measured as the difference between gross energy content and the energy lost as being undigested or indigestible.

children.label: digestible dry matter
children.definition: Amount of digestible fibre in a feed or forage.

children.label: digestible organic matter
children.definition: A percentage of energy and protein in forages/feed expressed as organic matter (DOM) intake minus fecal dry matter divided by dry matter intake times 100.

children.label: glycemic index
children.definition: A scale of the effects of foods on blood glucose concentrations shortly after ingestion.

children.label: glycemic load
children.definition: A quantitative value of a measured amount of a specific food that is equal to the glycemic index of that food multiplied by the carbohydrate content of that food.

children.label: digestible energy
children.definition: Energy in food or feed that is available to humans or animals by digestion, and measured as the difference between gross energy content and the energy lost in feces.

children.label: alkali spreading value
children.definition: A test for estimating the gelatinization temperature of starch utilizing a seven point scale of the degree of spreading of milled rice grains in potassium hydroxide solution.

children.label: drip loss
children.definition: The loss in weight of food products owing to extruding and dripping away of tissue juices, such as meat juices lost during the thawing of frozen meat.

children.label: marbling
children.definition: The presence of thin strips or flecks of fat within a meat cut. More marbling is usually associated with greater palatability.

children.label: food safety
children.definition: The fitness of a food for human consumption.

children.label: food safety objective
children.definition: The maximum frequency and/or concentration of a hazard in a food at the time of consumption that provides or contributes to the appropriate level of protection (ALOP).

children.label: food defense
children.definition: The overall process of protecting the food supply from intentional contamination, including preventive measures, surveillance, incident reporting and control.

children.label: HACCP
children.definition: A systematic approach to be used in food processing as a means to assure food safety.

children.label: CAC performance objective
children.definition: The maximum frequency and/or concentration of a hazard in a food at a specified step in the food chain before the time of consumption that provides or contributes to an FSO [food safety objective] or ALOP [appropriate level of protection], as applicable.

children.label: appropriate level of protection
children.definition: Degree of health protection considered acceptable by a member government establishing a sanitary or phytosanitary measure.

children.label: on-farm food safety
children.definition: Strategies and practices performed at the site of the production of food commodities in order to decrease the risk of foodborne illness.

children.label: CAC performance criterion
children.definition: The effect in frequency and/or concentration of a hazard in a food that must be achieved by the application of one or more control measures to provide or contribute to a PO [performance objective] or an FSO [food safety objective].

children.label: Food and Drug Administration Food Code
children.definition: A reference by the Food and Drug Administration guiding retailers like restaurants and grocery stores and institutions such as nursing homes on how to prevent foodborne illness.

children.label: FDA Food Safety Modernization Act
children.definition: FSMA was signed into law by President Obama on January 4, 2011. It aims to ensure the U.S. food supply is safe by shifting the focus from responding to contamination to preventing it.

children.label: food sanitation
children.definition: the promotion of hygiene and prevention of disease by maintenance of sanitary conditions for foods, food handlers, and food processing/preparation facilities and equipment.

children.label: microbiological criteria
children.definition: A microbiological criterion for food defines the acceptability of a product or a food lot, based on the absence or presence, or number of microorganisms including parasites, and/or quantity of their toxins/metabolites, per unit(s) of mass, volume, area, or lot.

children.label: microbiological standards
children.definition: A microbiological standard is a microbiological criterion that is a part of a law, ordinance, or administrative regulation. A standard is a mandatory criterion. Failure to comply with it constitutes violation of the law, ordinance, or regulation and will be subject to the enforcement policy of the regulatory agency having jurisdiction.

children.label: microbiological guidelines
children.definition: A microbiological guideline is a criterion that often is used by the food industry or a regulatory agency to monitor a manufacturing process. Guidelines function as alert mechanisms to signal whether microbiological conditions prevailing at critical control points or in the finished product are within the normal range. Hence, they are used to assess processing efficiency at critical control points and conformity with Good Manufacturing Practices. A microbiological guideline is an advisory criterion in that a given lot of food exceeding the limit for a nonpathogenic organism would not be taken off the market or even downgraded. Guidelines may be mandatory, however, in the sense that food company management and regulatory agencies may demand that the conditions responsible for persistent microbiological deficiencies be corrected without delay.

children.label: postharvest food safety
children.definition: Ensuring the fitness of food for human consumption during all steps once the food product leaves the farm.

children.label: culinary science
children.definition: The science of applying culinary arts to food sciences.

children.label: food technology
children.definition: The application of food science to the preservation, processing and preparation of foods, and to their packaging, storage and transportation.

children.label: retort pouches
children.definition: A flexible package in which food is sterilized and hermetically sealed for long-term unrefrigerated storage.

children.label: food handling
children.definition: Any aspect of the operations in the preparation, processing, transport, storage, packaging, wrapping, exposure for sale, service, or delivery of food.

children.label: nixtamalization
children.definition: Nixtamalization involves cooking and steeping corn in a lime solution, then washing and grinding the corn to form masa, a dough used to make tortillas, taco shells, corn chips, etc.

children.label: rendering
children.definition: The process of subjecting animal carcasses and parts, especially fatty tissues, to grinding, extraction, heat or other treatments to melt out the fats and convert them into meat byproducts.

children.label: dextrinization
children.definition: Breakdown of starch into dextrins due to heat, enzyme or acid stress.

children.label: defeathering
children.definition: The removal of feathers from poultry carcasses during the manufacture of poultry products.

children.label: smoking (food products)
children.definition: The application of smoke from burning wood to foods in order to preserve them and add a smoky flavor.

children.label: salting
children.definition: To treat, preserve or season with common salt.

children.label: sous vide
children.definition: Cooking in a plastic pouch.

children.label: pickling
children.definition: A method of preserving and flavoring foods by soaking them in brine or vinegar, often spiced.

children.label: reworks
children.definition: Foods which are reprocessed as alternative food products because of defects.

children.label: mash
children.definition: A crushed fermentable mixture, typically malt, grain meal or fruit, used to produce alcoholic beverages such as whiskey or beer.

children.label: cook-vide
children.definition: Unpacked product cooked in boiling water under vacuum conditions.

children.label: curing (food products)
children.definition: Any of a variety of processes that employ chemicals, smoke, sugar, or spices to preserve foods and/or modify tenderness, color or flavor; may be used in combination with drying.

children.label: food preservation
children.definition: A variety of methods used to maintain foods in an edible state.

children.label: food biopreservation
children.definition: The use of products from plants and microorganisms to preserve foods.

children.label: pasteurization
children.definition: Process of heating milk or other liquids to destroy microorganisms that can cause disease or spoilage while minimizing chemical changes that affect taste or aroma.

children.label: high-temperature short-time pasteurization
children.definition: The temperature and time combination for pasteurization of milk and milk products. The minimum for milk is 161 degrees F for at least 15 seconds. Higher temperatures are used in pasteurizing products of high solids content because of the protection afforded bacteria by solids.

children.label: cold pasteurization
children.definition: Non-thermal treatment of foods such as microfiltration, irradiation, or high pressure to kill microorganisms that could cause disease, spoilage, or undesired fermentation.

children.label: quantity food preparation
children.definition: Cooking methods, planning and preparation needed when preparing food for a large number of people.

children.label: food handling
children.definition: Any aspect of the operations in the preparation, processing, transport, storage, packaging, wrapping, exposure for sale, service, or delivery of food.

children.label: portion size
children.definition: The amount of a food served or consumed in one eating occasion. A portion is not a standardized amount, and the amount considered to be a portion is subjective and varies.

children.label: cuisine
children.definition: A style or method of food preparation.

children.label: food microbiology
children.definition: the presence of pathogenic and non-pathogenic bacteria, viruses and fungi in food and food products.

children.label: food toxins
children.definition: Any toxin found in food that has an adverse effect on an organism. The source of food toxin can be fungus, animal, plant or any microorganism.

children.label: food additives
children.definition: Any substance added to food to: 1) maintain product consistency, 2) improve or maintain nutritional value, 3) maintain palatability or wholesomeness, 4) provide leavening or control pH, or 5) enhance flavor or impart desired color.

children.label: food preservatives
children.definition: Substances capable of inhibiting, retarding or arresting the process of fermentation, acidification or other deterioration of foods.

children.label: food colorants
children.definition: Natural or synthetic dyes used as coloring agents in processed foods.

children.label: food law
children.definition: Laws and legislation that govern the quality, processing, packaging, labeling and safety of food, feeds and food products.

children.label: Food Quality Protection Act
children.definition: The Food Quality Protection Act was enacted on Aug. 3, 1996 to ensure the safety of food in the United States.

children.label: FDA Food Safety Modernization Act
children.definition: FSMA was signed into law by President Obama on January 4, 2011. It aims to ensure the U.S. food supply is safe by shifting the focus from responding to contamination to preventing it.

children.label: US Food Allergen Labeling and Consumer Protection Act
children.definition: FALCPA is an amendment to the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act and requires that the label of a food that contains an ingredient that is or contains protein from a "major food allergen" declare the presence of the allergen in the manner described by the law.
